item.description: Safwan bin umayyah was given payments despite being wealthy, this ruling was abrogated (to give to those to soften their hearts).
What is Taharah? The Prophet ﷺ said: “at-tuhoor shatrul imaan” Some of the ulema (not hanafi scholars) said that one who prays without taharah is committing kufr because it is mocking the religion.
#todo

The Prophet ﷺ was asked by the believers whether Allah is close or far to call out quietly or loudly, but Allah confirms that He is close.
It has to be bitareeqil isti’laa. Someone with high authority dictates or commands those of lower authority. The general usul in hanafi fiqh is al amru lilwujoob, a commandment is to be compulsory.
Sometimes an amr is an ibaahah, i.e. is it highlighting its permissibility. Example The ayah of a dog being trained to catch a prey and not kill it, then it is permitted to eat from it Maidah:4
Sometimes within the amr there is a hukm present and sometimes there is an external factor. There is hasan lighayrihi, and hasan lidhaatihi
Sometimes an amr is an irshad (a recommendation). Example The ayah of whenever you establish a contract, you should have witnesses.
When a commandment is given, is there repetition or not? Does the action need to be repeated more than once and continuously?
Sometimes an amr is an ikraam (to give value). Example The ayah of entering paradise with peace and complete satisfaction. Hijr:46
Sometimes an amr is an ihaanah (to ridicule or belittle someone) Example The ayah saying taste what you have earned, because you are honoured and respected.
What an evidence indicates towards i.e. trying to prove establishment of prayer from Qur’anic ayahs
Where it comes from i.e. Is it an established evidence? Is it Mutawatir?

item.title: Aam
item.description: ‘Alaa sabeeli ijtimaa: It is inclusive to many meanings This is a diagram that summarises Aam: Aam is divided into 2 types:

item.title: Azeemah (honourable)
item.description: Where the rule of the shariah is the asl, and there is no consideration for human limitations on whether it can be done or not, it is imposed upon everyone across the board.

item.title: Baqarah 142-143
item.description: The qibla was changed 16 months after hijrah. Allah says that the Jews will say the Muslims always oppose us. So he informed the Prophet ﷺ to say to them for Allah is the east and the west.

item.title: Baqarah 144
item.description: The Prophet ﷺ was leading the prayer at another masjid, and in his heart he wanted the qiblah to change, and he started looking up to the sky, in the hopes the qiblah changes, he did this 3/4 times and then this ayah was revealed.

item.title: Baqarah 145-147
item.description: When the qiblah changed, the jews made a ruckus about this, so Allah says that no matter what proof you bring, they will not accept.

item.title: Baqarah 150-152
item.description: Allah says to turn towards the new qiblah so that the enemies of Allah are not left with any hijjah (evidence) against them.

item.title: Baqarah 153-157
item.description: [[Ilmul rijaal/Abdullah ibn Mas’ud]] r.a.’s son died and the people came to visit him. But he was nowhere to be found.

item.title: Baqarah 158-160
item.description: When somebody does hajj and umrah, it is a rukn to do sa’ee, but Allah says “there is no harm” laa junaaha.

item.title: Baqarah 164
item.description: Allah speaks on the alternating between day and night, and the boats that carry cargo and bounties across the world. And the water that descends from the skies.

item.title: Baqarah 177
item.description: When the qiblah changed, the jews made a lot of noise about this. So Allah revealed that this isnt goodness, rather, goodness is whom believe in all of that is mentioned in the ayah and what he does.

item.title: Baqarah 178
item.description: In madinah there were two tribes, the aws and the khazraj, the aws were small and khazraj were big. They had a lot of fighting, the khazraj took an oath that they will take double the retribution for whoever is killed, for every free then they will kill 2 free etc.

item.title: Baqarah 182-183
item.description: When someone has a will and the executor makes mistakes, there is no harm in telling them how to do it correctly.

item.title: Baqarah 185
item.description: Ramadan is the only momth in the year mentioned in the Quran Maryam is the only name of a woman mentioned in the Quran

item.title: Dhahir
item.description: Definition Apparent Its so obvious it does not demand further elaboration or understanding. When you use that word, the listener know exactly what you intended.

item.title: Haqiqah
item.description: Definition A word being used in the meaning it was derived for Here is a diagram of Haqiqah: Example A person swears by Allah that they will not eat from this tree.

item.title: Introduction to Usul Fiqh
item.description: What is Usul Fiqh? It is a set of principles that allows you to derive rulings from their evidences The ahnaf were the first to establish usul In the past, scholars did not require them to be documented The principles of Fiqh are 4: From Dala’il Sam’iyyah: Kitab-ullah: 500+ ayaat relating to ahkam Sunnatu-rasooli: An Action of the Prophet (s.

item.title: Khafiy
item.description: Definition It seems apparent, but due to an external reason, there is an ambiguity that has been established. Example The ayah of the one who commits a robbery, hands are to be removed.

item.title: Khas
item.description: Translation: Specific There are 3 types of Khas Khasul fard A word used for a specific reason, or one person Qat’i and yaqeeni Nobody can be added to its understanding Khasul naw Specific to one type i.

item.title: Kinayah
item.description: Definition Ambiguous it is the opposite of Sareeh. The meaning behind the statement depends on the intention of the person. The context matters in this scenario.

item.title: Kitab us-sawm
item.description: Surah baqarah:183 Bukhari:1899 Musnad Ahmad:6637 Fasting is of 5 types: Fard 2. Fard mu’ayyah: specified i.e. ramadan 3. Fard ghayr mu’ayyan: non specified i.

item.title: Majaz
item.description: Definition The opposite of Haqiqah, it is the metaphorical meaning. The ahnaf and the shafi’is say that haqiqah and majaz come together under certain criteria:

item.title: Mu'awwal
item.description: Definition One that has been given precedence over all other meanings. Example Using the example of thalathata quroo.

item.title: Mufassar
item.description: Definition Explained When something is Dhahir, but the speaker gives a further elaboration on what he said. Example The angels prostrated, all of them together.

item.title: Muhkam
item.description: Definition Mufassar is such that in the time of the Prophet ﷺ, it could be abrogated, but muhkam, even at the time of the Prophet ﷺ, leaves no room for naskh

item.title: Mujmal
item.description: Definition Mujmal comprises of both Khafiy and Mushkil because using common sense, you can never get to the true understanding. It requires expert opinion to help you understand the meaning.

item.title: Mushkil
item.description: Definition The way we defined Nass was that there was an evidence to explain the word. In this, there was an ambiguity within the word itself.

item.title: Mushtarak
item.description: Definition It can potentially cater for many things in its meaning. This is the difference between Aam and this. It has the capacity for many but does not.

item.title: Mutashabih
item.description: Definition There is even more ambiguity than Mujmal. When there is so much ambiguity, that there is no understanding them and there is no room for elaboration.

item.title: Nass
item.description: Definition Theres a different between Dhahir and nass. The mujtahid would use the support of a daleel to ascertain the dhahir meaning.

item.title: Prohibitions
item.description: It is also under sabeelil isti’la: when a higher authority says to someone of lower authority to not do such and such.

item.title: Qat'i
item.description: Definition: Irrefutable

item.title: Sareeh
item.description: Definition Explicit In fiqh: A statement so explicit that there is no reasonable doubt that it can be anything else in meaning.

item.title: Umoomu Majaz
item.description: Definition Diverting from the literal meaning, towards the culturally understood and accepted meaning. Umoom: comes from aam. In other words; what the general society deem acceptable.
